root.prompt: A patient walks in looking anxious. They say they feel itchy and their throat feels tight. They seem short of breath. What would you do next?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Ask what changed right before symptoms started
choices.feedback: You learn the likely trigger, but you have not yet assessed how unstable the patient is right now.

next.prompt: Patient response: I ate a protein bar a few minutes ago. My throat feels tight and I feel lightheaded.

info.narration: You notice hives on their skin and their breathing is rapid.

choices.label: A
choices.feedback: Skin symptoms may improve, but airway swelling and low blood pressure are not treated.

next.prompt: Patient says: I feel worse. My throat feels tighter and I am more dizzy.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Activate EMS and give IM epinephrine
choices.feedback: The most time sensitive treatment is given and you trigger definitive care.

next.prompt: Patient says: After the injection, it feels a little easier to breathe. I am still scared. EMS arrives and transports the patient.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Assess airway and breathing right now
choices.feedback: You immediately focus on the time sensitive threat and can escalate quickly if needed.

next.prompt: Patient response: I am breathing fast and I feel like my throat is closing. I feel dizzy.

info.narration: You notice hives on their skin and their breathing is rapid. The patient looks worse.

choices.label: A
choices.feedback: Skin symptoms may improve, but airway swelling and low blood pressure are not treated.

next.prompt: Patient says: I feel worse. My throat feels tighter and I am more dizzy.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Activate EMS and give IM epinephrine
choices.feedback: IM epinephrine is first line when you suspect anaphylaxis with airway symptoms or hypotension.

next.prompt: Patient says: After the injection, it feels a little easier to breathe. I am still scared.

info.narration: Several minutes later, symptoms return. They look fatigued.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Wait for EMS since medication was already given
choices.feedback: Waiting can allow airway edema and hypotension to worsen again.

next.prompt: Patient says: I feel worse again. My throat is getting tight and I feel weak.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Give a second IM epinephrine dose
choices.feedback: Repeating epinephrine can stabilize symptoms while awaiting definitive care.

next.prompt: Patient says: After the second injection, it improves again. I can breathe a little easier. EMS arrives and transports the patient.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Offer water and have them sit upright
choices.feedback: Oral intake is not appropriate when nausea and airway tightness are present, and it delays assessment.

next.prompt: Patient says: I can try but I feel nauseated and my throat feels tight.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Ask about past medical history first
choices.feedback: Background history matters, but delaying airway assessment can miss rapid deterioration.

next.prompt: Patient says: I have allergies but I have never felt this bad. My throat feels tight.
